choices.B: Unlike route-maps, only RPL supports extcommunity sets to group extended communities.
choices.A: Unlike RPL, route-maps are supported with IPv4 address families only.
choices.C: Unlike route-maps, only RPL is designed for bulk configuration of multiple devices.
choices.D: Unlike RPL, route-maps are designed for BGP protocol only.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Of course B

Selected Answer: B
route-maps use extcommunity-listm while rpl uses extcommunity-set, it should be B

questions.question_text: What is the difference between RPL and route-maps?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The default SRLB range is from 15000 to 15999, so I do not see C as the right answer here. Looks more like D for me.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.

//IMG//


A network engineer is enabling a segment routing solution with these requirements:

• A service provider is using the default and nondefault SID range for interface allocation.
• 192.168.10.0/30 interface should add an index value of 20 SID from the default range.
• 192.168.30.0/30 interface should use a nondefault range and index value of 50.

Which configuration must be implemented to meet the requirements?

choices.C: It must be configured with send labels
choices.D: It must be configured with PIC edge
choices.A: It must be configured for graceful restart
choices.B: It must be configured with a route reflector

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The BGP routers that connect different areas together are the ABRs that act as a BGP Route-Reflector. These devices use the Next-Hop-Self feature, in order to avoid the need to have all Next-Hops of the complete Autonomous System within the IGP, instead of only the IP addresses of the PEs and the central infrastructure. Loop detection is completed based upon the BGP Cluster-IDs.

Selected Answer: B
RRs will use next-hop-self. By default, routers only do this for eBGP learned routes. In IOS-XR, we can override this behavior with ibgp policy out enforce-modifications, which tells the router to use next-hop-self for eBGP and iBGP learned routes.
B

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Router 1 is a core ABR in a Cisco Unified MPLS environment. All of the router 1 BGP peers are established, but traffic between customers is failing. Which BGP configuration must be added to the configuration?

comments.content: Agree, it might be the key on this question

discussion.content: Since p2p network type does advertise a host route, I believe we need to use some different network-type here. NBMA for example.

SIMULATION
-


Guidelines
-
This is a lab item in which tasks will be performed on virtual devices.

• Refer to the Tasks tab to view the tasks for this lab item.
• Refer to the Topology tab to access the device console(s) and perform the tasks.
• Console access is available for all required devices by clicking the device icon or using the tab(s) above the console window.
• All necessary preconfigurations have been applied.
• Do not change the enable password or hostname for any device.
• Save your configurations to NVRAM before moving to the next item.
• Click Next at the bottom of the screen to submit this lab and move to the next question.
• When Next is clicked, the lab closes and cannot be reopened.


Topology
-

//IMG//



Tasks
-

Troubleshoot and configure OSPF according to the topology to achieve these goals:

1. R1 and R2 must not have OSPF BR/DR election over their E0/0 interfaces and must not advertise the OSPF host route for the OSPF connected neighbors.
2. E0/0 interfaces on R1 and R2 to be preferred over E0/1 interfaces for OSPF traffic. Only the numerical value of 15 is allowed.
3. Set the OSPF hello interval to 5 and the OSPF dead interval to 10 between R1 and R2 on interface E0/1.

DRAG DROP
-

Drag and drop the characteristics from the left onto the corresponding routing protocols on the right.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
It is B for sure. as the others had stated
OSPF
It operates on the Network Layer
Routing between areas is distributed through the backbone

IS-IS
Backbone routers reside in any area
Uses the system ID to identify routers on the network

Should be:
OSPF
It operates on the Network Layer
Routing between areas is distributed through the backbone

IS-IS
Backbone routers reside in any area
Uses the system ID to identify routers on the network

I would say:
OSPF - It operates on the network layer, Routing between areas is distributed through the 
backbone area
IS-IS: Backbone routers reside in any area, It uses the system ID to identify routers on the network
